title-group.article-title: A General Method of Approximation. Part I

abstract.p: In this paper we study two families of functions, viz. $F$ and $H$, and show how to approximate the functions considered in the interval [0, 1]. The functions are assumed to be real when the argument is real. We define $$F = \{f; \text{(i)}f(\frac{1}{2} + x), \text{(ii)}f(0) = f(1) = 0, \text{(iii)}f(x)\quad\text{is analytic in a sufficiently large neighborhood of}\quad x = 0\},$$ $$H = \{h; \text{(j)} h(\frac{1}{2} + x) = -h(\frac{1}{2} - x), \text{(jj)}h(0) = h(1) = 0, \quad\text{(jjj)}h(x)\quad\text{is analytic in a sufficiently large neighborhood of}\quad x = 0\}.$$ The approximations are defined in the interval [0, 1] by $$\min \int^1_0 \bigg(f(x) - \sum^k_{n = 1} c_{n,k}[x(1 - x)]^n\bigg)^2x^q(1 - x)^q dx$$ and $$\min \int^1_0 \bigg(h(x) - (1 - 2x) \sum^k_{n = 1} C_{n,k}[x(1 - x)]^n\bigg)^2x^q(1 - x)^qdx,$$ where $q \in \{0, 1, 2,\ldots\}$. The associated matrices are analyzed using the theory of orthogonal polynomials, especially the Jacobi polynomials $G_n(p, q, x)$. We apply the general theory to the basic trigonometric functions $\sin(x)$ and $\cos(x)$.
